page_content:
Underground Fibre and Conduit
Architecture for FSA

Purpose:
The objective of this guideline is to give a clear outline of Xplore best practices and standard on fibre drop
conduit and drop cable design architecture in FSA design.
The ultimate goal is to place the facilities by the most economical method, minimizing material costs to
provide a service enabled network.
Scope:
The guideline covers the key aspect such as conduit design consideration, drop cable installation criteria,
and conduit sizes for different purposes. The guideline only covers drop conduit to Single
Family/Business Unit premise, Multi-Tenant Unit premise is not covered in this document.
Applicability:
This document is applicable to Outside Plant fibre engineers, designers, construction managers, and
project mangers involved in the planning, design, and implementation of underground conduit systems
and fibre drop cable design and installation for Xplore Fibre-To-The-Premise.
References to existing Xplore National Standards – Fibre:
• 3.2.1 Drop Placement Guideline
• 3.2.4 Locatable Muletape and Tonerwire
• 3.2.6 Fibre Underground Placement Standard

# 1 Definitions and Abbreviations

FDH
Fibre Distribution Hub
FOSC
Fibre Optic Splice Closure
FP
Flower Pot
FSA
Fibre Servicing Area
MPT
Multi-Port Terminal
MxU
Multi (Dwelling/Tenent) Unit
NID
Network Interface Device
P/L
Property Line
RoE
Right of Entry
SxU
Single (Family/Business) Unit

# 2 Introduction

This guideline outlines and defines the best practices and standards for the placement of new distribution
conduit and fibre drop cable within Xplore Fibre Servicing Area (FSA) design, offering insights to
engineers and technicians to optimize network performance, increase installation efficiencies and
minimize maintenance efforts.
The main characteristics of the underground drop cable and conduit architecture are:
• Every Single Family/Business Unit (SxU) premise will have a drop conduit placed to property line.
• A fibre drop cable will be placed to demarcation location, where Network Interface Device (NID) is
placed, IF there is a Right-of-Entry (RoE) agreement signed prior to FSA build.
• Drop conduit will end at a flower pot placed at property line (P/L) if there is no RoE agreement
signed prior to FSA build.
• Maximum drop conduit length between pull boxes is 100m (standard) and 200m in rural settings.
• Round Drop cable is recommended in underground pulling application.
• All permit applications should have placement of flowerpot on the drawing.
**See Figure 1** for a typical drop placement for SxU premise.

MPT inside ground level service box 6. 18/14mm drop conduit (Microduct) to property line 7. "Flower Pot" - Circular handhole 8. Drop cable to NID or coiled inside FP. Remove FP when drop placed to house FDH: Fibre Distribution Hub FOSC: Fibre Optic Splice Closure MPT: Multi-Port Terminal NID: Network Interconnection Device P/L: Property Line - SxU w/ RoE - SxU w/o RoE]

page_content:
**Figure 1: Underground Drop Placement Standard Overview**

# 3 Conduit

## 3.1 Mainway Routing

Xplore’s preferred method is to place of one (1) 50mm conduit as main way at a minimum where the
distribution cable needs to be extended within the FSA footprint. In most cases the placement of 1-50mm
conduit will be sufficient for placement of the cable for the FSA build, for the future growth as well as
expansion, should it be required. A second conduit of 50mm should be placed at this time if the designer
feels that:
• There is a chance of substantial growth in the future.
• The route is the major route of the distribution network.
The current cable capacities along with future and restorative capacity requirements must be considered
when determining the size and number of conduits required through a section.
A conduit will be considered full once 70% of its area volume has been occupied.
Distribution cables, Transport cables, and MPT tails should be placed inside main way conduit.

## 3.2 Drop Conduit Routing

Note: Xplore will place drop conduit to all Single Family or Business Unit (SxU) property.
Xplore’s preferred method is to place one (1) 18/14mm or 14/10mm conduit as drop conduit to property line
(P/L) at the minimum. **See Figure 2** for details.
The path from the property line to NID, usually on the side of the building, can be direct buried if possible.
Drop paths from Service Box (SB), where Multiport Terminal (MPT) is located, to P/L or flower pot must
remain within the public Right-of-Way or documented utility easement and must never transition from
private property to private property.
It is recommended to keep both side of the conduits capped until drop cable placement is completed.
In the public right-of-way the drop conduit length should be kept to a maximum of 100m from the
terminal location to P/L or flower pot, to keep the pulling length to a reasonable distance.
In some instances, such as in rural settings, there may be the need to design a longer duct length due to
location of the terminal in relation to the P/L or flower pot. We would recommend to keep this distance at
a maximum of 200m. Should you require longer distances we recommend a pull box in between to allow
for easier installation at time-of-service order.
Note: Some jurisdictions may have certain parameters in place which can impact the design and build
such as:
• Use of existing vs. new infrastructure.
• Above grade vs. below grade - jurisdiction preference with factors such as snow removal and
water table nuances. A pedestal should be used instead of Service Box.

page_content:
# 4 Flower Pot

The flower pot (FP) needs to be installed with the lid flush to ground level. This will allow for easy access
to the drop for future installation to the building. Whether it is temporary or permanent in nature, try to
install the flower pot in the least intrusive location for the occupants. The flower pot has an Electric Marker
(EM) equipped locatable lid.
When proposing flower pot placement, the location must be as close as possible to the back of Right-of-
Way & property line, adjacent to the other utilities. Where possible it should be placed on a joint property
line in order to feed both premises from the same flower pot.
In areas where the location of the flower pot at property line is not feasible on the demarcation side due to
concrete coverage or other obstructions, it can be placed in the most strategic location which will allow a
successful drop to be placed in the future.

## 4.1 Flower Pot Installation Criteria

• Only install flower pot for a SxU premise if a Right-of-Entry (RoE) is not signed during the time of
FSA construction. In this scenario, the drop conduit ends in a flower pot is required.
Figure 2 shows the proper design and placement of main way conduit, drop conduit, and flower pot.

**Figure 2: Mainway & Drop Conduit and Flower Pot Placement**

# 5 Demarcation Location

Xplore’s demarcation location should be in the vicinity of the existing electrical meter and Telco / CATV
Network Interface Device (NID).

page_content:
# 6 Drop Cable

Xplore has approved two types of fibre drop cables:
• Pre-Connectorized 1F Round Drop cable (Round drop) for Underground application.
• Pre-Connectorized 1F Flat Drop cable (Flat drop) for Aerial application.
All drops will run from strategically placed MPT location to feed every SxU premise in the FSA.
The drop conduit must be placed with a tracer wire up to the property line.
All underground designs will require 18/14mm or 14/10mm to be used for drop conduit.
Note: Xplore is only authorized to extend fibre facility to a SxU demarcation (from property to NID) if there
is a RoE agreement signed.
**See Figure 3** for reference.
